comment_data.body:
Reason: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/949ef785a4e7aa7868c9605b6bbed15c3f4beab9/toxcore/Messenger.c#L149

If we change this, it needs to be changed in various places. It is indeed a bug, because it depends on system endianness. On big endian systems, friend requests probably don't work.
How are your thoughts about using ntohl() and htnl() from arpa/inet.h for that? Or is it not portable enough?

>  On big endian systems, friend requests probably don't work.

lol... OH FUCK

Yes, htonl would be acceptable for this (for now). Ideally we would have a binary codec abstraction like @nurupo proposed. The htonl function is already used in various places. The concern is not around whether and how we can do it, but currently most (probably all) nospams in existing friend addresses in existence are written in little endian. Only those that were retrieved from a tox instance running on a big endian system would have big endian. To make it portable, we would need to enforce little endian. I would prefer to make it big endian, and when adding a friend, we could try adding both endiannesses in the transitional period while the old little endian friend addresses are phased out.

> On big endian systems, friend requests probably don't work.

Turns out they work, it's just that the nospam set function was expecting nospam in big endian and the nospam get function was returning it in a big endian.
Moved to v0.0.5 to follow the attached pull.

rename.from: nospam value is reversed in array returned by tox_self_get_address()
rename.to: nospam value is reversed in array returned by `tox_self_get_address()`

labels.description: Bug fix for the user, not a fix to a build script
labels.name: bug

title: nospam value is reversed in array returned by `tox_self_get_address()`
